placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder is for the full legal name of the company issuing this Simple Agreement for Future Equity (SAFE). It serves to clearly identify the legal entity that is undertaking the obligations and issuing future equity under this agreement. Users need to fill this to correctly identify the issuing company, which is crucial for legal enforceability and defining the party responsible for the SAFE's terms. The question to ask the user is: "What is the full legal name of the company issuing this SAFE?" This placeholder represents the legal name of the corporation. The expected value type is text (company name). It must be the exact legal name as registered with the relevant authorities. Examples include "Acme Innovations Inc." or "Global Tech Solutions LLC". This field is critical for legal and business purposes as it identifies the main party to the contract. It is related to PLACEHOLDER_0005 and PLACEHOLDER_0009, which should contain the same company name. Validation should ensure it is a valid legal company name.

placeholders.full_paragraph_text: THIS CERTIFIES THAT in exchange for the payment by [Investor Name] (the “Investor”) of $[_____________] (the “Purchase Amount”) on or about [Date of Safe], [Company Name], a [State of Incorporation] corporation (the “Company”), issues to the Investor the right to certain shares of the Company’s Capital Stock, subject to the terms described below.
placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder is for the full legal name of the investor, whether an individual or an entity, who is providing the investment under this SAFE. Its purpose is to clearly identify the party that will receive future equity and holds rights under this agreement. Users need to fill this to correctly identify the investor party to the SAFE. The question to ask the user is: "What is the full legal name of the investor? Is it an individual or an entity?" This placeholder represents the full legal name of the investor. The expected value type is text (person or entity name). It must be the exact legal name of the investor. Examples include "Jane Doe" or "Venture Capital Partners L.P.". This field is essential for defining who holds the rights under the SAFE and is directly referenced as 'the Investor' throughout the document. It relates to the investor signature block. Validation should ensure it is a valid legal name.

placeholders.full_paragraph_text: THIS CERTIFIES THAT in exchange for the payment by [Investor Name] (the “Investor”) of $[_____________] (the “Purchase Amount”) on or about [Date of Safe], [Company Name], a [State of Incorporation] corporation (the “Company”), issues to the Investor the right to certain shares of the Company’s Capital Stock, subject to the terms described below.
placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder specifies the exact monetary amount, in U.S. Dollars, that the investor is paying to the company in exchange for the SAFE. This amount is referred to as the 'Purchase Amount' and is fundamental to the SAFE's terms, as it forms the basis for future equity conversion calculations. Users need to fill this to record the precise investment amount. The question to ask the user is: "What is the exact monetary amount the investor is paying for this SAFE?" This placeholder represents the principal investment amount. The expected value type is currency (USD). It must be a positive numerical value, typically in whole dollars or with two decimal places. Examples include "100,000" or "50,000.00". This is a core financial term of the SAFE, directly impacting the investor's entitlements upon conversion or a liquidity event. It is explicitly defined as the 'Purchase Amount' and is used in conversion calculations in Section 1(a) and 1(b). Validation should ensure it is a positive number and formatted as currency.

placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder indicates the effective date on which the SAFE agreement is entered into and becomes legally binding. This date is used to establish the official start of the agreement and the point at which the investment is considered to have been made. Users need to fill this to set the official start date of the SAFE. The question to ask the user is: "What is the effective date of this SAFE agreement?" This placeholder represents the date the SAFE agreement becomes effective. The expected value type is date. It must be a valid date format, such as MM/DD/YYYY or Month Day, Year. Examples include "January 1, 2024" or "12/15/2023". This date is important for tracking the investment timeline and the commencement of rights and obligations under the SAFE. There are no directly related fields, but the date impacts the 'on or about' phrasing for the purchase. Validation should ensure it is a valid calendar date.

placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder reiterates the full legal name of the company within the main body of the SAFE document, specifically identifying it as a corporation of a certain state. Its purpose is to maintain consistent identification of the company throughout the agreement after its initial mention. Users should typically find this pre-filled based on the initial company name provided. The question to ask the user (if not pre-filled) is: "What is the full legal name of the company as defined earlier in the document?" This placeholder represents the legal name of the corporation. The expected value type is text (company name). It must exactly match the name provided in PLACEHOLDER_0001 to ensure consistency and avoid ambiguity. Examples include "Acme Innovations Inc." or "Global Tech Solutions LLC". This ensures clarity regarding the issuing entity throughout the legal text. It is directly related to PLACEHOLDER_0001 and PLACEHOLDER_0009. Validation should ensure it matches the value in PLACEHOLDER_0001.

placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder specifies the U.S. state where the company is legally incorporated. This information is vital for establishing the company's legal domicile and the jurisdiction under which its corporate governance is primarily regulated. Users need to fill this to accurately state the company's state of incorporation. The question to ask the user is: "In which U.S. state is the company legally incorporated?" This placeholder represents the name of the U.S. state. The expected value type is text (state name). It must be a valid U.S. state or territory name. Examples include "Delaware", "California", or "New York". This is crucial for corporate legal matters, including compliance and legal standing. There are no directly related fields, but it complements the company's legal identity. Validation should ensure it is a recognized U.S. state name.

placeholders.sentence_after: See Section 2 for certain additional defined terms.
placeholders.paragraph_context_before: This Safe is one of the forms available at  and the Company and the Investor agree that neither one has modified the form, except to fill in blanks and bracketed terms.
placeholders.surrounding_text: The “Post-Money Valuation Cap” is $[_____________].  See Section 2 for certain additional defined terms.
placeholders.full_paragraph_text: The “Post-Money Valuation Cap” is $[_____________].  See Section 2 for certain additional defined terms.
placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder defines the 'Post-Money Valuation Cap' for the SAFE, a critical financial term that sets the maximum valuation at which the SAFE will convert into equity. This cap benefits the investor by ensuring they receive a predetermined ownership percentage if the company's valuation exceeds this amount at the time of an equity financing. Users need to fill this to establish this key financial term of the agreement. The question to ask the user is: "What is the agreed-upon Post-Money Valuation Cap for this SAFE?" This placeholder represents a numerical value for the maximum company valuation (in U.S. Dollars) for conversion purposes. The expected value type is currency (USD). It must be a positive numerical value, typically in whole dollars. Examples include "5,000,000" or "10,000,000". This cap directly influences the 'Safe Price' and 'Liquidity Price' definitions and is referenced in Section 1(a) for conversion calculations and Section 5(a) for amendment provisions. Validation should ensure it is a positive number and formatted as currency.

placeholders.full_paragraph_text: (f)	All rights and obligations hereunder will be governed by the laws of the State of [Governing Law Jurisdiction], without regard to the conflicts of law provisions of such jurisdiction.
placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder designates the U.S. state whose laws will govern the interpretation, validity, and enforcement of the entire SAFE agreement. Choosing a governing law jurisdiction provides legal certainty and a predictable legal framework for any contractual disputes or interpretations. Users need to fill this to establish the legal jurisdiction for the agreement. The question to ask the user is: "Which state's laws should govern this SAFE agreement?" This placeholder represents the name of the U.S. state. The expected value type is text (state name). It must be a valid U.S. state or territory name. Examples include "Delaware", "California", or "New York". This is a critical legal provision, especially in the event of litigation or differing interpretations of the contract terms. There are no directly related fields, but it impacts the legal enforceability of the entire document. Validation should ensure it is a recognized U.S. state name.

placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder is located in the signature block and is reserved for the full legal name of the company. Its purpose is to clearly identify the legal entity that is formally executing the SAFE agreement by signature. Users should typically find this pre-filled based on the initial company name provided at the beginning of the document. The question to ask the user (if not pre-filled) is: "What is the full legal name of the company as it appears at the beginning of the document, to be printed above the signature?" This placeholder represents the full legal name of the corporation. The expected value type is text (company name). It must exactly match the name provided in PLACEHOLDER_0001 and PLACEHOLDER_0005 to ensure consistency. Examples include "Acme Innovations Inc." or "Global Tech Solutions LLC". This is essential for proper identification of the signing party and legal validity of the signature. It is related to PLACEHOLDER_0001 and PLACEHOLDER_0005. Validation should ensure it matches the value in PLACEHOLDER_0001.

placeholders.note_about_page: Page number is estimated. Actual pages depend on Word rendering.
placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder is for the printed full name of the individual who is authorized to sign the SAFE agreement on behalf of the company. Its purpose is to clearly identify the signatory. Users need to fill this with the name of the person signing. The question to ask the user is: "What is the full printed name of the authorized individual signing on behalf of the company?" This placeholder represents the full legal name of the individual. The expected value type is text (person name). It should be in a standard name format. Examples include "John P. Smith" or "Sarah L. Chen". This is crucial for verifying the authority and identity of the person executing the document for the company. It is related to PLACEHOLDER_0011 (the signatory's title). Validation should ensure it is a valid person's name.

placeholders.note_about_page: Page number is estimated. Actual pages depend on Word rendering.
placeholders.llm_context: This placeholder is for the official corporate title of the individual signing the SAFE agreement on behalf of the company. Its purpose is to indicate the signatory's capacity and authority to legally bind the company to the terms of the agreement. Users need to fill this with the signatory's official title. The question to ask the user is: "What is the official title of the authorized individual signing on behalf of the company?" This placeholder represents the official corporate title of the individual. The expected value type is text (job title). It must be an official corporate title. Examples include "Chief Executive Officer", "President", or "Secretary". This is important for confirming the signatory's legal authority to execute the document for the company. It is related to PLACEHOLDER_0010 (the signatory's name). Validation should ensure it is a recognized corporate title.
